title: Isaiah Chapter 5 Quiz - Multi-Level
description: An enhanced quiz on Isaiah chapter 5 with Easy, Medium, Hard, and Theological levels. Each level has 15 carefully crafted questions. Choose your difficulty and dive in!

easy.title: Isaiah Chapter 5 Quiz - Easy Level
easy.description: Perfect for beginners! Test your basic knowledge of Isaiah Chapter 5.

questions.question: What did the wellbeloved plant in his vineyard according to Isaiah 5:2?
options: Choicest vine
Olive trees
Fig trees
Palm trees
questions.correctAnswer: Choicest vine
questions.explanation: Isaiah 5:2 says the wellbeloved planted the vineyard with the choicest vine.

questions.question: According to Isaiah 5:7, the vineyard of the LORD of hosts is a metaphor for what?
options: House of Israel
The city of Babylon
The land of Egypt
The kingdom of Assyria
questions.correctAnswer: House of Israel
questions.explanation: Isaiah 5:7 states that the vineyard of the LORD of hosts is the house of Israel.

questions.question: Who is asked to judge between the speaker and the vineyard in Isaiah 5:3?
options: Inhabitants of Jerusalem and men of Judah
Kings and princes
Prophets and priests
Foreign nations
questions.correctAnswer: Inhabitants of Jerusalem and men of Judah
questions.explanation: Isaiah 5:3 asks the inhabitants of Jerusalem and men of Judah to judge betwixt the speaker and his vineyard.

questions.question: What was the expected fruit of the vineyard in Isaiah 5:2?
options: Grapes
Figs
Olives
Dates
questions.correctAnswer: Grapes
questions.explanation: Isaiah 5:2 says the wellbeloved looked that the vineyard should bring forth grapes.

questions.question: What did the vineyard actually bring forth instead of the expected fruit according to Isaiah 5:2?
options: Wild grapes
No fruit
Olives
Figs
questions.correctAnswer: Wild grapes
questions.explanation: Isaiah 5:2 states that the vineyard brought forth wild grapes instead of good grapes.

questions.question: What will happen to the vineyard as described in Isaiah 5:5?
options: The hedge will be taken away and the wall broken down
It will be watered and pruned
It will bear much fruit
It will be sold to strangers
questions.correctAnswer: The hedge will be taken away and the wall broken down
questions.explanation: Isaiah 5:5 says the hedge will be taken away and the wall broken down so it will be eaten up and trodden down.

questions.question: According to Isaiah 5:6, what will grow up in the vineyard when it is laid waste?
options: Briers and thorns
Flowers and herbs
Grains and herbs
Trees and bushes
questions.correctAnswer: Briers and thorns
questions.explanation: Isaiah 5:6 states that when the vineyard is laid waste, briers and thorns will come up.

questions.question: Who are described as joining house to house and laying field to field in Isaiah 5:8?
options: Those who seek to monopolize land
The poor and needy
The prophets
The priests
questions.correctAnswer: Those who seek to monopolize land
questions.explanation: Isaiah 5:8 warns woe unto them that join house to house and lay field to field until no place is left.

questions.question: What is the result of many houses being desolate according to Isaiah 5:9?
options: They will be without inhabitant
They will be full of joy
They will be blessed
They will be protected
questions.correctAnswer: They will be without inhabitant
questions.explanation: Isaiah 5:9 says many houses shall be desolate, even great and fair, without inhabitant.

questions.question: What does Isaiah 5:11 say about those who rise up early and continue until night?
options: They follow strong drink
They pray and fast
They work hard in the fields
They study the law
questions.correctAnswer: They follow strong drink
questions.explanation: Isaiah 5:11 says woe unto them who rise up early that they may follow strong drink till wine inflames them.

questions.question: True or False: Isaiah 5:20 warns against calling evil good and good evil.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Isaiah 5:20 clearly states woe unto them that call evil good, and good evil.

questions.question: True or False: Isaiah 5:16 says the LORD of hosts will be humbled in judgment.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Isaiah 5:16 says the LORD of hosts shall be exalted in judgment, not humbled.

questions.question: True or False: According to Isaiah 5:22, it is a woe unto men who are mighty to drink wine and strong drink.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Isaiah 5:22 pronounces woe unto them that are mighty to drink wine and men of strength to mingle strong drink.

questions.question: Complete the verse from Isaiah 5:1: 'Now will I sing to my wellbeloved a song of my beloved touching his ________.'
options: vineyard
kingdom
people
mountain
questions.correctAnswer: vineyard
questions.explanation: Isaiah 5:1 says the song is touching his vineyard.

questions.question: Complete this verse from Isaiah 5:25: 'Therefore is the anger of the LORD kindled against his people, and he hath stretched forth his hand against them, and hath smitten them; and the hills did tremble, and their ______ were torn in the midst of the streets.'
options: carcases
trees
walls
cities
questions.correctAnswer: carcases
questions.explanation: Isaiah 5:25 mentions their carcases were torn in the midst of the streets.

medium.title: Isaiah Chapter 5 Quiz - Medium Level
medium.description: Ready for more? Apply biblical truths from Isaiah Chapter 5 to real-life situations.

questions.question: How does Isaiah 5 teach us about God's expectations for faithfulness and fruitfulness in our lives?
options: God expects us to produce good fruit as evidence of our faith
God does not require any fruitfulness from us
God is pleased with any effort regardless of results
God only cares about sacrifices and offerings
questions.correctAnswer: God expects us to produce good fruit as evidence of our faith
questions.explanation: Isaiah 5:1-2 uses the vineyard metaphor where God expects good grapes but receives wild grapes, illustrating His desire for righteousness and good works from His people (Isaiah 5:1-2, 5:7).

questions.question: A fellow believer struggles with feelings of inadequacy in serving God. Based on Isaiah 5, what truth can you share about God's care and involvement in our lives?
options: God carefully tends and prepares us for fruitfulness
God leaves us to grow on our own
God punishes immediately without warning
God expects perfection from the start
questions.correctAnswer: God carefully tends and prepares us for fruitfulness
questions.explanation: Verses Isaiah 5:2-4 describe how God fenced, cleared stones, planted the choicest vines, built a tower, and made a winepress, showing His intentional care and preparation for our growth.

questions.question: What warning about complacency and indulgence in life does Isaiah 5:11-12 give that can help believers maintain spiritual discipline?
options: Avoid excessive drinking and neglecting God's work
Indulge in all pleasures without restraint
Ignore spiritual responsibilities when tired
Celebrate life with music and drink as priority
questions.correctAnswer: Avoid excessive drinking and neglecting God's work
questions.explanation: Isaiah 5:11-12 warns against rising early to follow strong drink and feasting without regard to the work of the Lord, emphasizing the need for spiritual focus and discipline.

questions.question: How does the vineyard metaphor in Isaiah 5:7 relate to our responsibility as believers in family and church life?
options: We are God's chosen people expected to live justly and righteously
We are free to do as we please without accountability
We should isolate ourselves from others
We are only responsible for personal success
questions.correctAnswer: We are God's chosen people expected to live justly and righteously
questions.explanation: Isaiah 5:7 identifies the vineyard as the house of Israel and men of Judah as God’s pleasant plant, highlighting the expectation for justice and righteousness among His people in community.

questions.question: A believer feels discouraged about injustice around them. What insight from Isaiah 5:16 can encourage them regarding God's judgment and holiness?
options: The LORD will be exalted in judgment and holy in righteousness
God ignores injustice and lets it continue
Human judgment is better than divine judgment
God prefers mercy over justice in all cases
questions.correctAnswer: The LORD will be exalted in judgment and holy in righteousness
questions.explanation: Isaiah 5:16 assures that God is exalted in judgment and sanctified in righteousness, encouraging believers to trust His righteous governance (Isaiah 5:16, 5:7, 5:24).

questions.question: According to Isaiah 5:20, how should believers discern moral truth in daily life?
options: Avoid calling evil good and good evil
Accept all opinions as equal
Follow popular culture's definitions
Ignore distinctions between right and wrong
questions.correctAnswer: Avoid calling evil good and good evil
questions.explanation: Isaiah 5:20 condemns those who call evil good and good evil, urging believers to uphold biblical truth and moral clarity in their judgments.

questions.question: What does Isaiah 5:8 teach about honesty and integrity in stewardship and work ethic?
options: It warns against greedily accumulating property to the detriment of others
It encourages hoarding wealth regardless of others
It suggests working minimally to keep possessions
It promotes dishonest gain for personal advantage
questions.correctAnswer: It warns against greedily accumulating property to the detriment of others
questions.explanation: Isaiah 5:8 pronounces woe on those who join house to house and lay field to field, illustrating a warning against selfish accumulation and lack of generosity.

questions.question: True or False: Isaiah 5:13 teaches that lack of knowledge and disregard for God's work can lead to spiritual captivity and distress.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Isaiah 5:13 explains that God's people go into captivity because of no knowledge, and their leaders are famished and thirsty, highlighting consequences of ignoring God's ways.

questions.question: How can the warning in Isaiah 5:18 about iniquity help believers resist temptation and persevere in trials?
options: It illustrates how sin can become habitual and binding if not resisted
It shows that sin is easy to avoid without effort
It teaches that sin has no consequences
It encourages believers to ignore sin
questions.correctAnswer: It illustrates how sin can become habitual and binding if not resisted
questions.explanation: Isaiah 5:18 compares drawing iniquity with cords and sin as with cart ropes, indicating how sin entangles and binds if unchecked, urging perseverance and vigilance.

questions.question: What practical lesson about humility can believers learn from Isaiah 5:15?
options: Both the mighty and the mean will be humbled before God
Only the weak will be humbled
Pride is acceptable if you are strong
Humility is unnecessary for believers
questions.correctAnswer: Both the mighty and the mean will be humbled before God
questions.explanation: Isaiah 5:15 teaches that the eyes of the lofty shall be humbled and the mighty brought down, showing God's sovereign humbling of all people regardless of status.

questions.question: A believer asks about God's discipline. Based on Isaiah 5:24-25, what biblical truth would you share about consequences for rejecting God's law?
options: Rejecting God's law leads to destruction and continued judgment
God ignores disobedience
Rejecting God has no lasting effect
God immediately forgives without consequences
questions.correctAnswer: Rejecting God's law leads to destruction and continued judgment
questions.explanation: Isaiah 5:24-25 describes how rejecting God's law results in destruction like fire consuming stubble and ongoing divine anger and judgment.

questions.question: True or False: Isaiah 5:22 warns against the strength to drink wine as a sign of weakness and loss of self-control.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Isaiah 5:22 pronounces woe on those mighty to drink wine and men of strength to mingle strong drink, highlighting the dangers of excessive drinking and lack of self-control.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: Isaiah 5:6 teaches that when God's vineyard is forsaken, it shall not be pruned nor dug; but there shall come up _____ and _____.
options: briers, thorns
flowers, fruits
grapes, olives
grass, wheat
questions.correctAnswer: briers, thorns
questions.explanation: Isaiah 5:6 says the vineyard will be laid waste with no pruning or digging, and briers and thorns shall come up, symbolizing neglect and judgment.

questions.question: What does Isaiah 5:23 teach about integrity in justice and leadership?
options: It condemns those who justify the wicked for reward and remove righteousness
It praises leaders who accept bribes
It encourages favoritism in judgment
It says justice is optional for rulers
questions.correctAnswer: It condemns those who justify the wicked for reward and remove righteousness
questions.explanation: Isaiah 5:23 pronounces woe on those who justify the wicked for reward and take away righteousness from the righteous, emphasizing integrity in leadership.

questions.question: How does Isaiah 5:26-29 describe God's provision for justice and protection in times of trouble?
options: God will summon nations swiftly to execute judgment
God abandons His people in trouble
God delays intervention indefinitely
God encourages people to fight alone
questions.correctAnswer: God will summon nations swiftly to execute judgment
questions.explanation: Isaiah 5:26-29 describes God lifting an ensign and hissing to nations who come quickly and powerfully, symbolizing divine judgment and protection for His purposes.

hard.title: Isaiah Chapter 5 Quiz - Hard Level
hard.description: Challenge yourself with deep analysis and cross-biblical connections from Isaiah Chapter 5.

questions.question: What does the vineyard in Isaiah 5 symbolically represent?
options: The house of Israel and the men of Judah
The kingdom of Babylon
The temple in Jerusalem
The land of Egypt
questions.correctAnswer: The house of Israel and the men of Judah
questions.explanation: Isaiah 5:7 explicitly states that the vineyard of the LORD of hosts is the house of Israel and the men of Judah his pleasant plant, symbolizing God's chosen people.

questions.question: In Isaiah 5, what is the result of the vineyard bringing forth wild grapes instead of good grapes?
options: The removal of its hedge and destruction
An increase in harvest
The planting of more choicest vines
The building of another winepress
questions.correctAnswer: The removal of its hedge and destruction
questions.explanation: Verses 5 and 6 describe that because the vineyard brought forth wild grapes, the LORD will remove its hedge, break down its wall, and lay it waste.

questions.question: Which literary device is most prominent in the description of the vineyard and its failure in Isaiah 5?
options: Allegory
Parable
Chiasm
Hyperbole
questions.correctAnswer: Allegory
questions.explanation: Isaiah 5 uses allegory to describe the vineyard as Israel, illustrating their failure and God's judgment through symbolic imagery (Isaiah 5:1-7).

questions.question: What is the significance of the 'wild grapes' in the context of ancient Near Eastern symbolism?
options: They symbolize corruption and failure to produce righteousness
They indicate prosperity and blessing
They represent foreign nations
They suggest divine favor and protection
questions.correctAnswer: They symbolize corruption and failure to produce righteousness
questions.explanation: In the ancient Near East, vineyards symbolized prosperity and blessing; wild grapes represent inferior fruit, symbolizing Israel’s moral failure (Isaiah 5:2-4).

questions.question: How does Isaiah 5:20 warn against moral relativism?
options: By condemning those who call evil good and good evil
By praising the wise and prudent
By commanding strict adherence to ritual purity
By encouraging social justice
questions.correctAnswer: By condemning those who call evil good and good evil
questions.explanation: Isaiah 5:20 explicitly pronounces woe on those who invert moral values, warning against the dangers of moral relativism.

questions.question: What historical context helps explain the social critique in Isaiah 5:8 regarding joining house to house?
options: The concentration of land by wealthy elites during the late monarchy period
The Babylonian exile policies
The Assyrian invasions
The rebuilding of the temple
questions.correctAnswer: The concentration of land by wealthy elites during the late monarchy period
questions.explanation: The verse criticizes the greed and land grabbing practices of the elite, reflecting social inequities in Judah before the exile (Isaiah 5:8).

questions.question: Which New Testament passage echoes Isaiah 5:20’s condemnation of calling evil good?
options: Romans 1:28-32
John 3:16
Acts 2:38
Revelation 21:4
questions.correctAnswer: Romans 1:28-32
questions.explanation: Romans 1:28-32 recounts a similar moral inversion and the consequences of rejecting God’s truth, paralleling Isaiah’s warning.

questions.question: In Isaiah 5, what does the phrase 'the LORD of hosts shall be exalted in judgment' (verse 16) imply about God's nature?
options: God is both holy and righteous, and His judgment is just
God is indifferent to human affairs
God favors the mighty over the weak
God’s judgment is arbitrary
questions.correctAnswer: God is both holy and righteous, and His judgment is just
questions.explanation: Verse 16 highlights God’s holiness and righteousness as the foundation of His exalted and fair judgment.

questions.question: True or False: Isaiah 5 describes the punishment of Israel as a consequence of despising the word of the Holy One of Israel.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Isaiah 5:24 states the root cause of Israel’s punishment is casting away the law of the LORD and despising His word.

questions.question: What does the lifting up of an ensign to the nations in Isaiah 5:26 foreshadow in biblical history?
options: The calling of foreign armies to execute judgment on Israel
The birth of the Messiah
The establishment of the Davidic kingdom
The return from exile
questions.correctAnswer: The calling of foreign armies to execute judgment on Israel
questions.explanation: The verse foreshadows God summoning distant nations as instruments of judgment, historically linked to Assyrian or Babylonian invasions.

questions.question: Which literary structure is evident in the progression from Isaiah 5:18 to 5:23's series of woes?
options: A parallelism of woes illustrating escalating sins
A chiasm focusing on divine mercy
A prophetic lament
A narrative parable
questions.correctAnswer: A parallelism of woes illustrating escalating sins
questions.explanation: Verses 18-23 contain a series of woes structured in parallel fashion, each condemning specific sins in escalating severity.

questions.question: What does the command to not prune or dig the vineyard in Isaiah 5:6 symbolize in the prophetic message?
options: God’s withdrawal of care and protection from Israel
An agricultural blessing
A call for greater human effort
The establishment of a new covenant
questions.correctAnswer: God’s withdrawal of care and protection from Israel
questions.explanation: Not pruning or digging symbolizes neglect and judgment, indicating God will no longer care for Israel’s spiritual growth (Isaiah 5:6).

questions.question: How does Isaiah 5:29's description of the nations roaring like young lions function within the chapter's overall theme?
options: It portrays the swift and unstoppable judgment coming upon Israel
It celebrates Israel’s military victory
It symbolizes God’s protection over Jerusalem
It predicts a peaceful reign of the Messiah
questions.correctAnswer: It portrays the swift and unstoppable judgment coming upon Israel
questions.explanation: The roaring nations metaphor indicates fierce, swift judgment that will overtake Israel as a consequence of their sins (Isaiah 5:29).

questions.question: Fill in the blank: Isaiah 5:10 states, 'Yea, ten acres of vineyard shall yield ______ bath, and the seed of an homer shall yield an ephah.'
options: one
two
five
ten
questions.correctAnswer: one
questions.explanation: The verse highlights the poor yield, indicating judgment and scarcity as a result of Israel’s disobedience (Isaiah 5:10).

questions.question: What is the significance of the 'winepress' built in the vineyard according to Isaiah 5:2?
options: It symbolizes the place of judgment and wrath
It represents celebration and joy
It is a symbol of peace and prosperity
It indicates the temple altar
questions.correctAnswer: It symbolizes the place of judgment and wrath
questions.explanation: The winepress metaphor, common in prophetic literature, often symbolizes divine judgment, as grapes are crushed to produce wine or wrath (Isaiah 5:2).

theological.title: Isaiah Chapter 5 Quiz - Theological Level
theological.description: Deep biblical theology from Isaiah Chapter 5 that unites all believers. Explore foundational truths about God, creation, and humanity.

questions.question: What does the vineyard in Isaiah 5 symbolize in relation to God's people?
options: The house of Israel and the men of Judah as God's pleasant plant
A kingdom of earthly kings and their armies
The temple and its priests only
A metaphor for the nations surrounding Israel
questions.correctAnswer: The house of Israel and the men of Judah as God's pleasant plant
questions.explanation: Isaiah 5:7 explicitly states that the vineyard of the LORD is the house of Israel and the men of Judah his pleasant plant, indicating God's special relationship with His covenant people. This symbolism aligns with passages like Psalm 80:8-16 and John 15:1-8 where Israel and believers are depicted as a vineyard or branches chosen by God.

questions.question: What was the expectation of the owner of the vineyard after planting the choicest vine, and what was the result?
options: He expected good grapes but got wild grapes
He expected wild grapes and got good grapes
He expected no grapes and got wild grapes
He expected fruitless vines and got good grapes
questions.correctAnswer: He expected good grapes but got wild grapes
questions.explanation: Isaiah 5:2 describes how the owner planted the choicest vine expecting it to produce good grapes, but instead it bore wild grapes. This metaphor reveals God's disappointment in Israel's sinful behavior despite His care, reflecting Romans 11:17-21 and Matthew 21:33-43 where fruitlessness indicates judgment.

questions.question: What consequences does God declare will come upon the vineyard due to its failure?
options: The hedge will be taken away, walls broken down, and it will be laid waste
It will be blessed with extra rain and abundant fruit
It will be transplanted to a better soil
It will be given to another gardener immediately
questions.correctAnswer: The hedge will be taken away, walls broken down, and it will be laid waste
questions.explanation: In Isaiah 5:5-6, God says He will remove protection from the vineyard and allow it to be destroyed, symbolizing judgment upon Israel for disobedience. This theme of divine judgment for unfaithfulness is consistent with Ezekiel 15:1-8 and Hosea 10:1-2.

questions.question: According to Isaiah 5, what did God look for in His people, and what did He find instead?
options: He looked for justice but found oppression; for righteousness but found a cry
He looked for sacrifice but found neglect; for prayer but found silence
He looked for obedience but found rebellion; for worship but found idolatry
He looked for peace but found war; for faith but found doubt
questions.correctAnswer: He looked for justice but found oppression; for righteousness but found a cry
questions.explanation: Isaiah 5:7 declares God's expectation of justice and righteousness from Israel but laments their failure, which is a key theme in prophetic literature such as Amos 5:24 and Micah 6:8, emphasizing God's desire for ethical conduct rather than mere ritual.

questions.question: What warning does Isaiah give about those who amass houses and fields until there is no room for others?
options: Woe to them, because many houses will be desolate and without inhabitant
Blessings will come upon their wealth and descendants
They will be exalted as leaders over Israel
They will be protected by God's favor
questions.correctAnswer: Woe to them, because many houses will be desolate and without inhabitant
questions.explanation: Isaiah 5:8-9 pronounces woe on those who greedily accumulate property at the expense of others, predicting desolation as judgment. This echoes similar denunciations in Micah 2:1-2 and Jeremiah 22:13-17 about social injustice and divine retribution.

questions.question: What does Isaiah say about the fruitfulness of the land as a sign of judgment?
options: Ten acres of vineyard shall yield one bath, and the seed of an homer shall yield an ephah
The land shall produce abundant harvests and prosperity
The vineyards will produce only grapes for wine
The fields will be fertile and yield double crops
questions.correctAnswer: Ten acres of vineyard shall yield one bath, and the seed of an homer shall yield an ephah
questions.explanation: Isaiah 5:10 describes the land's diminished yield as a sign of divine judgment for Israel's sins. This theme is consistent with Leviticus 26:20 and Deuteronomy 28:38 where disobedience results in poor harvests.

questions.question: What critique does Isaiah offer concerning those who rise early to pursue strong drink and continue until wine inflames them?
options: Woe to them for their indulgence and neglect of God's work
Blessings will come to those who enjoy wine responsibly
They are wise in their own eyes and prudent
They are justified by their reward
questions.correctAnswer: Woe to them for their indulgence and neglect of God's work
questions.explanation: Isaiah 5:11-12 criticizes those who prioritize drunkenness over reverence for God, highlighting their disregard for divine works. This warning parallels Proverbs 23:29-35 and Ephesians 5:18 about the dangers of excessive drinking.

questions.question: What is the reason given for the captivity of God's people in this chapter?
options: Lack of knowledge and ignorance of God's law
Military defeat by foreign armies
Economic hardship and famine
Natural disasters and plagues
questions.correctAnswer: Lack of knowledge and ignorance of God's law
questions.explanation: Isaiah 5:13 explains that the people went into captivity because they lacked knowledge, a theme echoed in Hosea 4:6 and Romans 1:21 where ignorance of God leads to judgment and downfall.

questions.question: What does Isaiah say about the fate of the mighty and the mean man in the judgment of God?
options: The mean man will be brought down, and the mighty man will be humbled
The mighty will reign forever, and the mean will be exalted
Both will be rewarded for their deeds
The mean will be exalted and the mighty will remain powerful
questions.correctAnswer: The mean man will be brought down, and the mighty man will be humbled
questions.explanation: Isaiah 5:15 teaches that in God's judgment, social status is overturned: the lowly are brought down and the mighty humbled. This aligns with Luke 1:52 and James 4:6 which emphasize God's sovereign reversal of human pride.

questions.question: How does Isaiah describe the attitude of those who 'draw iniquity with cords of vanity' and 'sin as if with a cart rope'?
options: They hasten the work of God to see His counsel quickly
They repent and seek God's mercy
They patiently wait for God's timing
They sincerely pray for forgiveness
questions.correctAnswer: They hasten the work of God to see His counsel quickly
questions.explanation: Isaiah 5:18-19 speaks of people eager to see God's judgment come swiftly, yet they do so mockingly or without true repentance. This attitude contrasts with Habakkuk 2:3-4 and 2 Peter 3:9 where God's timing is purposeful and merciful.

questions.question: What inversion of moral values does Isaiah condemn in this chapter?
options: Calling evil good, and good evil; putting darkness for light, and light for darkness
Honoring the poor and despising the rich
Preferring silence over worship
Choosing the weak over the strong
questions.correctAnswer: Calling evil good, and good evil; putting darkness for light, and light for darkness
questions.explanation: Isaiah 5:20 condemns moral relativism where people invert right and wrong. This condemnation is echoed in Romans 1:28-32 and Proverbs 17:15 where perversion of justice and truth leads to judgment.

questions.question: What does Isaiah say about those who are 'wise in their own eyes' and 'prudent in their own sight'?
options: Woe unto them
They shall be honored by God
They will be rulers over the nations
They are examples to the faithful
questions.correctAnswer: Woe unto them
questions.explanation: Isaiah 5:21 pronounces woe on those who are arrogant in their own wisdom, reflecting Proverbs 3:7 and 1 Corinthians 3:18 which warn against self-conceit and exaltation apart from God.

questions.question: According to Isaiah 5, what is the consequence for those who justify the wicked for reward and take away the righteousness of the righteous?
options: Their roots shall be as rottenness and their blossoms go up as dust
They shall be rewarded with wealth and power
They will be protected by the law
They will be forgiven if they repent
questions.correctAnswer: Their roots shall be as rottenness and their blossoms go up as dust
questions.explanation: Isaiah 5:23-24 describes the destructive end of those who pervert justice for gain. This echoes Proverbs 17:23 and Psalm 7:14-16 where corrupt judges and unjust gain lead to ruin.

questions.question: What is the nature of God's anger against His people as described in Isaiah 5?
options: God's anger is kindled, His hand is stretched out, and judgment continues
God withdraws His anger quickly after a brief warning
God ignores their sins and delays judgment indefinitely
God's anger is expressed only in mild correction
questions.correctAnswer: God's anger is kindled, His hand is stretched out, and judgment continues
questions.explanation: Isaiah 5:25 emphasizes the intensity and persistence of God's judgment upon His people due to their rebellion, consistent with Jeremiah 30:23-24 and Nahum 1:2 where God's wrath is powerful and sustained.

questions.question: What does God do to summon the nations against His people, according to Isaiah 5?
options: He lifts up an ensign and hisses unto them from the ends of the earth
He sends angels to persuade the nations
He calls His people to fight their enemies alone
He commands the mountains to swallow the enemies
questions.correctAnswer: He lifts up an ensign and hisses unto them from the ends of the earth
questions.explanation: Isaiah 5:26 describes God raising a banner and signaling the distant nations to come swiftly against Israel. This imagery is found in Zechariah 9:14 and Revelation 19:11-16 where God's sovereign control directs the course of nations for judgment.
